awd_titl_txt: A Geometric Control Framework for Enabling Behavior-Based Planning and Locomotion of Undulatory Robots
awd_abstract_narration:
Equipped with a slender and over-actuated body, snake-like robots have the ability to maneuver through complex environments. These platforms have been heralded for their locomotive advantages when navigating through rubble, tight spaces, and other areas hard to reach with standard robots. Yet, without a reliably systematic feedback control framework, snake-like robots cannot make the transition from teleoperation to full autonomy. This award will support advances in the dynamic modeling of snake locomotion from fundamental mechanical principles. These models are important for controlling robotic snakes, and other undulatory systems, and will remove a key obstacle to autonomy. The award will also support fundamental research into the role that scales play in snake locomotion, including the creation of robotic snake skin that will enable snake-like robots to realize the locomotive advantages of actual snake scales. The end goal of the project is to demonstrate autonomous snake operation through an unknown environment. Doing so will bring robotic snakes significantly closer to being deployable for search and rescue, inspection, and operation in hazardous environments. The research findings will also apply to similar biologically-inspired robots, such as swimming and flapping-wing flying robots. The popularity of robotics will be leveraged to create engaging educational and outreach activities in promotion of engineering mathematics.

Snake-like robots are high-dimensional, articulated limbless robots that exploit control over a continuous morphological feature to achieve locomotion in a variety of ways. Science has exposed the physical principles underlying locomotion, while engineers have reproduced the fundamental mechanisms and can teleoperate these robots. However the creation of actionable feedback control policies is not fully resolved. What is missing is the physical and mathematical formulation that bridges the gap from achievement of undulatory gaits to the controlled execution of motion along a planned path. To address the gap, this project will design, and demonstrate the performance benefits of, biologically inspired scale fabrication for robotic snakes. The designed scales will reproduce the structural and anistropic friction properties of snake scales. Further, the research will use spatio-temporal averaging to derive reduced control equations for undulatory robotic systems where the body's internal degrees of freedom are modeled in the continuum. Achieving these two objectives will resolve a long-standing achievement gap between biologically inspired, undulatory robots and traditionally engineered robots.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The main project goal was to derive a general purpose modeling approach for snake-like robots, capable of predicting the movement of such robots for a variety of gaits. Using these models would then permit planning and control of movement for snake-like robots. Contemporary modeling approaches are often specialized to specific gaits or non-existent for some gaits. Most progress on the modeling front has been for snake-like robots with wheel-based robot-ground interaction, as opposed to the body-ground associated to biological snakes. The project successfully derived the intended general purpose modeling approach and verified its predictive capabilities. Feedback control using four gaits was made possible using the models: a caterpillar-like rectilinear gait, lateral undulation, sidewindings, and a turn-in-place gait. In a related vein, planning and trajectory generation was achieved based on the models, thereby demonstrating the ability to plan and complete locomotion tasks. The shape-centric modeling framework is the first such approach to theoretically predict movement and experimentally confirm the accuracy of the predicted movement using an experimental snake robot.

A critical part of the success involved engineering a mechanical design for robotic snakes that reproduces the correct body-world interactions. Chassis modules with special scale-like geometry were fabricated and placed on the snake-like robot motor modules to be in contact with the ground.  The scale-like geometry reproduces the anisotropic friction known to characterized actual snake scales. Adding these physical components to the robot replicates the body-ground interactions responsible for snake locomotion. Experimental studies of a snake-like robot equipped with the scales and lacking the scales discovered that the scales not only contribute to enhanced movement, but they provide stabilizing effects in the direction of travel to ground irregularities and ground-based disturbances. Snake-like robot locomotion, in the wheel-less setting, is enhanced through the addition of ventral scales.

The project attracted many undergraduate students, ultimately involving around 15 students over the course of the award. One third of these students went on to pursue graduate studies (MS or PhD). Additionally, the software used to interface with the robots smart servomotors was repurposed for use by lab-based projects in robotics and computer vision courses, thereby contributing to instructional resources. The snake-like robot itself was also used to promote interest in STEM fields and Robotics to hundreds of youth through the creation and exhibition of locomotion demonstrations.

The modeling approach is quite general and applies to other locomotive robot designs with elongated or slender bodies that interact with the environment to move. Evidence in favor of a shape-centric modeling approach was provided through the experimental verification of a soft-robot inchworm movement model, and through efforts to translate the multi-gait, kinematic modeling, planning, and trajectory synthesis approach to other soft-robots, a starfish-like robot in particular. Both of these activities involved collaboration with experts in soft robotics, thereby extending the framework more broadly.

Overall, the shape-centric modeling framework achieved its proposed objectives and can be used to model planar movement of snake-like robots over diverse terrains. The success suggests that a similar approach may be applied to three-dimensional movement of snake-like robots over non-flat terrain and even of contact-based movement of snake-like robots over flat terrain. In this manner, the shape-centric modeling framework has the potential to enable additional movement capabilities and affordances of snake-like robots such that their envisioned benefits for infrastructure and post-disaster inspection may be realized.

 


Last Modified: 11/02/2022
Modified by: Patricio A Vela

Images (1 of )
  • Incorporation of the Turn-in-Place gait (red traces on path) into the planning and trajectory tracking modules of the snake robot autonomy stack permit navigation through tighter scenarios that the translation dominant Rectilinear gait (green trace) cannot achieve.
    Alexander Chang
    Creative Commons
    Patricio A Vela
    Multi-gait path planning and trajectory tracking with Rectilinear and Turn-in-Place gaits.
  • Rectilinear gait trajectory traces with robot snake overlay (green: planned; purple: executed).
    Alexander H. Chang
    Creative Commons
    Patricio A Vela
    Path planning and trajectory tracking using rectilinear gait.
  • Bent body (left) versus wedged (right) sidewinding gaits. Wedged sidewinding has better turning ability. It would work best for path planning and trajectory tracking purposes.
    Alexander Chang
    Creative Commons
    Patricio A Vela
    Experimental comparison of two sidewinding gait models: bent-body and wedged.
  • Turn-in-place gait snapshots (left 3 images) and traced trajectory (right-most). Adding a turn-in-place gait improves maneuverability of the robotic snake.
    Alexander Chang
    Creative Commons
    Patricio A Vela
    Movement snapshots of a standing wave Turn-in-Place gait for robotic snakes.
  • Artificial snake scale design improves lateral undulation gait locomotion over terrain with small-scale irregularities, here concrete. Leads to better forward motion and more consistent direction of motion. Left: Robot snake with scales. Top-right: With scales. Bottom-right: Without scales.
    Alexander Chang
    Creative Commons
    Patricio A Vela
    Trajectory comparison of robot snake with and without scales.
  • Robotic snake demonstration includes communication of scientific findings on snake locomotion and engineering efforts to replicate their maneuverability using commercially available components and fabrication techniques.
    Josie Giles
    Creative Commons
    Patricio A Vela
    STEM outreach efforts at Fernbank Center�s Annual Science Day (2018 & 2019).
